prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our goal for the CO 2-1 line is to resolve it at high enough spectral resolution to fit profile shapes and thus estimate the cold molecular gas outflow rate, following e.g. Feruglio et al 2010, Cicone et al 2013. To estimate the line flux we adopt two approaches. First, we scale from previous observations of CO in AGN (e.g. Papadopoulos et al 2008, Xia et al 2012), accounting for differences in redshift and IR luminosity. This gives estimates in the range 3.5 - 7.0 Jy km s-1. Second, we extract L_FIR from the IR SED (Farrah et al 2007) and then use the relation in Solomon et al 2005 to estimate CO intensities. This approach yields typical values of 6-7 Jy Km s-1. We thus adopt a conservative value of 3.5 Jy Km s-1, and a line width of 800 km s-1. Since we expect the outflow to have a spatial extent of <3kpc, the CO emission will be unresolved by ALMA, and the flux density per beam is 3.8 mJy. This observation can thus be performed in any array configuration, except the most extended.
Based on previous studies (e.g. Cicone et al 2013), we require high S/N in ~50 km s-1 bins to measure profile shape well enough to derive outflow rates. Using the 1875 MHz bandwidth, 50 km s-1 corresponds to approximately 18.8 MHz. The CO 2-1 line will easily fit within the 1875MHz bandwidth, even if it is as broad and as blueshifted as any previously observed CO line in AGN. We adopt 18 MHz as the frequency width used for sensitivity calculations. We adopt a requirement of an average SN=12 per 50 km s-1 bin, thus an RMS sensitivity of 0.318mJy. This should give a similar quality spectrum to those in Cicone et al 2013, which resulted in accurate CO mass outflow rates. Using the ALMA OT time estimator, the total time, including all overheads, is 2.35 hours. We include aadditional basebands to obtain continuum measurements near to the line, and smooth the FDM findows by a factor 4 to avoid excessive data rates.

For the CO 4-3 line we follow a similar approach as for CO 2-1 to estimate the expected line flux, yielding a conservative estimate of 4 Jy km s-1, or 5mJy. For this line we do not require a profile shape, but only a measure of the line flux and an estimate of the line width. We thus assume that we want an average SN=10 per 200 km s-1 bin. This translates to a bandwidth for sensitivity of 150MHz, and an RMS sensitivity of 0.5mJy, yielding a total time, including overheads, of 0.475 hours. Like the CO2-1 line, we expect this line to also be spatially unresolved.

For the CO 5-4 line we estimate 4.5 Jy km s-1, or 5.5mJy. For this line we also only require a measure of the line flux and an estimate of the line width, so we again assume an average SN=10 per 200 km s-1 bin. This translates to a bandwidth for sensitivity of 200MHz, and an RMS sensitivity of 0.55mJy, yielding a total time, including overheads, of 0.51 hours. Like the CO2-1 line, we expect this line to also be spatially unresolved.

For the CO 6-5 line we estimate 4.7 Jy km s-1, or 5.7mJy. For this line we also only require a measure of the line flux and an estimate of the line width, so we again assume an average SN=10 per 200 km s-1 bin. This translates to a bandwidth for sensitivity of 225MHz, and an RMS sensitivity of 0.57mJy, yielding a total time, including overheads, of 0.525 hours. Like the CO2-1 line, we expect this line to also be spatially unresolved.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to study Quasar mode feedback via the most direct approach possible; measure how efficiently an AGN-driven wind couples to the molecular gas in a rapidly star-forming BAL QSO host galaxy. To do so, we will observe CO 2-1 to measure the kinetic flux in molecular gas, and three further CO lines to estimate what is heating the ISM. We will then compare the kinetic flux of the molecular gas to the kinetic flux in the BAL wind, measured via existing data. This will be the first study to directly estimate how efficiently an AGN-driven wind may transfer momentum to the fuel reservoir for star formation, complemented by knowledge of what is heating the molecular gas. Our target is ideal for this study. It shows powerful BAL winds, is extremely IR-luminous, harbors an intense starburst, and is a member of a class of QSOs for which there is solid evidence that Quasar mode feedback is in the act of happening. It is also well placed in redshift for ALMA to observe multiple CO lines. We will use these data both to publish an important paper on Quasar mode feedback on this object, and to plan a future, larger proposal targeting QSOs drawn from the same parent population.
